prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to observe with ALMA band 3 the N2H+ (1-0) at rest frequency of 93.17340 GHz with a spatial resolution of 2.5", a spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s and a sensitivity of 15 mJy, corresponding to ~0.3 K. We expect a peak line flux density of at least 1.0 K and a line width of ~1 km/s, therefore these requirements are ideal to trace the dynamical structure of starless clump with N2H+ observations (e.g. Beuther & Henning 2009, Beuther et al. 2013). Within this spectral window we get also a ladder of CH3CH (5-4) transitions for which we have enough resolution and sensitivity to identify if star formation is already occurring within some of these clumps. We require ACA observations to complement the 12m array for these spectral line observations in order to recover the extended emission in the clumps. With this setup, we require a total of 7.02h for this science goal including ACA observations and calibrations.

We aim to observe with ALMA band 3 the N2H+ (1-0) at rest frequency of 93.17340 GHz with a spatial resolution of 2.5", a spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s and a sensitivity of 15 mJy, corresponding to ~0.3 K. We expect a peak line flux density of at least 1.0 K and a line width of ~1 km/s, therefore these requirements are ideal to trace the dynamical structure of starless clump with N2H+ observations (e.g. Beuther & Henning 2009, Beuther et al. 2013). Within this spectral window we get also a ladder of CH3CH (5-4) transitions for which we have enough resolution and sensitivity to identify if star formation is already occurring within some of these clumps. We require ACA observations to complement the 12m array for these spectral line observations in order to recover the extended emission in the clumps. With this setup, we require a total of 10.18h for this science goal including ACA observations and calibrations.

For these continuum observations, we ask for the best spatial resolution achievable with ALMA band 3, 0.5", and a sensitivity of 0.10 mJy. This spatial resolution allows us to resolve spatial structures down to ~0.01 pc at d~5.8 kpc, the furthest target in this science goal, enough to resolve the small fragments (e.g. Beuther & Henning 2009). The requested sensitivity allows us to identify fragments down to ~24 solar masses at d~5.8 kpc and down to ~9 solar masses at 3.5 kpc, the closest clump. We do not require ACA observations for the continuum, since we expect that the cores are compact (e.g. Peretto et al. 2013) and fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Therefore, we request a total of 34.70 min including calibration and overheads

For these continuum observations, we ask for the best spatial resolution achievable with ALMA band 3, 0.5", and a sensitivity of 0.10 mJy. This spatial resolution allows us to resolve spatial structures down to ~0.01 pc at d~5.9 kpc, the furthest target in this science goal, enough to resolve the small fragments (e.g. Beuther & Hanning 2009). The requested sensitivity allows us to identify fragments down to ~25 solar masses at d~5.9 kpc and down to ~10 solar masses at d~3.6 kpc, the closest clump. We do not require ACA observations for the continuum, since we expect that the cores are compact (e.g. Peretto et al. 2013) and fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Therefore, we request a total of 39.94 min icluding calibration and overheads

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Massive stars are important in determining the chemical and physical structure of the interstellar medium in galaxies, but the mechanism by which massive stars are formed is still unrevealed. In particular, the accretion mechanism to form a warm high-mass protostellar core from its progenitor cloud is still mostly unexplored, primarily due to the lack of resolution and sensitivity prior to ALMA. We aim to use ALMA to study the earliest stages of high-mass star formation, observeing a carefully selected sample of starless and pre-stellar clumps, the missing link between the clouds and the protostellar cores

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, Manchester, University of
